title: How to Crochet a Crocodile Stitch

steps.headline: Make a slip knot and place it onto your crochet hook.
steps.description: Wrap your working yarn around your index and middle finger twice. Then, pull the first loop on your hook over the second loop on your hook. Place the loop on your crochet hook. Then, tug the tail of your yarn to tighten the loop. Choose a crochet hook and yarn that are compatible. Check the yarn label for a hook size recommendation if you are unsure.

steps.headline: Chain 21.
steps.description: With the slipknot on the hook, wrap your working yarn over your hook 1 time and pull this yarn through the slip knot. This new loop is your first chain. To make another chain, bring the yarn over the hook, and pull it through the loop again. Keep going until you have made a chain of 21.Tip: Make sure to keep the working yarn taut as you crochet to ensure that your chain is not too loose.

steps.headline: Double crochet into the fourth chain from the hook.
steps.description: Wrap the yarn over the hook 1 time and then insert it into the fourth chain from the hook. Yarn over the hook again and pull the yarn through the chain. Then, yarn over again and pull through 2 loops. Yarn over 1 more time, and pull through the remaining 2 loops to complete the stitch. This completes 1 double crochet stitch and the chain stitches next to the stitch also count as a double crochet stitch.

steps.headline: Double crochet 1 time into each chain.
steps.description: To complete the foundation row, double crochet 1 time into every chain in the row. Go all the way to the end of the chain. Make sure to keep the chain straight as you work to avoid twisting the stitches.

steps.headline: Turn your work to the side at the end of the row.
steps.description: After you finish the last double crochet stitch in the row, turn the foundation row to the side. This will make it easier for you to access the stitches that you need to crochet around in the next row.

parts.name: Crocheting the First Row of Scales

steps.headline: Chain 3 and work 3 double crochet stitches under the post.
steps.description: Loop the yarn over the hook and pull it through to make a chain. Then, repeat this sequence 2 more times to make a total of 3 chain stitches. This chain of 3 will count as a double crochet stitch. Follow the chain with 3 double crochet stitches worked under the post of the first double crochet stitch in the row.Tip: Make sure to keep the working yarn taut as you work to ensure that the stitches are not too loose.

steps.headline: Chain 1.
steps.description: After you complete the third double crochet stitch, make a chain of 1. This will provide some slack between the rows of double crochet stitches and help to form the scale shape.

steps.headline: Double crochet 4 times around the next post.
steps.description: Turn the work to the opposite side and locate the next post. Use your fingers to pull it out slightly so that it is easier for you to access it. Then, work 4 double crochet stitches under the post to complete the first scale. Make sure that the bases of these stitches are facing the bases of the first 4 double crochet stitches.

steps.headline: Skip the next 2 stitches.
steps.description: After you complete the first scale, skip the next 2 stitches in the row. This will create space between the scales and make them more visible.

steps.headline: Repeat the sequence to the end of the row.
steps.description: After you have completed 1 scale, repeat the sequence to make more scales. However, instead of chaining 3 to begin the next stitch, simply double crochet 4 times around the post. Then, chain 1, double crochet 4 times around the next post, and skip 2 as before.

steps.headline: Chain 3 and turn your work.
steps.description: Once you have finished working your first row of scales, make a chain of 3. Loop the yarn over the hook and pull through to make the first chain. Repeat this 2 more times. Then, turn your work around so that you are looking at it from the opposite side.Tip: Always hold your hook in your dominant hand. If you are right-handed, hold the hook in your right hand. If you are left-handed, hold the hook in your left hand.

steps.headline: Double crochet into the first stitch in the row.
steps.description: Locate the first stitch in the row and then work a double crochet stitch through it. Yarn over your hook, pull it through 1. Then, yarn over again and pull through 2. Yarn over again 1 more time and pull through 2 again to complete the stitch. This will help to smooth out the work and create a foundation for the next row of scales.

steps.headline: Work a double crochet stitch into the center of the first crocodile stitch.
steps.description: Locate the space in between the 2 rows if double crochet stitches from your previous row. Then, yarn over your hook and insert the hook into this space. Complete 1 double crochet stitch into the space of this stitch.

steps.headline: Slipstitch and double crochet 1 time between the scales.
steps.description: Insert the crochet hook through the 2 layers of stitches in between the first set of scales. Then, loop the yarn over the hook and pull it all the way through the scales. Loop the yarn over the hook again and work a double crochet stitch through the scales. These are the spaces you skipped in the last row.

steps.headline: Repeat the stitch sequence to the end of the row.
steps.description: Continue to work the same pattern for the rest of the row. This will complete the second foundation row and allow you to add more scale rows. When you are ready to finish your project, make sure to work a foundation row as your last row.

steps.headline: Repeat the last 2 rows to add more scales.
steps.description: After you have completed your second foundation row, work another row of scales. The, follow that with another foundation row. Keep repeating this sequence of rows until your work is the desired length. Cut and tie off your work as usual when you have completed your project.

text: Creating the Foundation Row Make a slip knot and place it onto your crochet hook. Wrap your working yarn around your index and middle finger twice. Then, pull the first loop on your hook over the second loop on your hook. Place the loop on your crochet hook. Then, tug the tail of your yarn to tighten the loop. Choose a crochet hook and yarn that are compatible. Check the yarn label for a hook size recommendation if you are unsure. Chain 21. With the slipknot on the hook, wrap your working yarn over your hook 1 time and pull this yarn through the slip knot. This new loop is your first chain. To make another chain, bring the yarn over the hook, and pull it through the loop again. Keep going until you have made a chain of 21.Tip: Make sure to keep the working yarn taut as you crochet to ensure that your chain is not too loose. Double crochet into the fourth chain from the hook. Wrap the yarn over the hook 1 time and then insert it into the fourth chain from the hook. Yarn over the hook again and pull the yarn through the chain. Then, yarn over again and pull through 2 loops. Yarn over 1 more time, and pull through the remaining 2 loops to complete the stitch. This completes 1 double crochet stitch and the chain stitches next to the stitch also count as a double crochet stitch. Double crochet 1 time into each chain. To complete the foundation row, double crochet 1 time into every chain in the row. Go all the way to the end of the chain. Make sure to keep the chain straight as you work to avoid twisting the stitches. Turn your work to the side at the end of the row. After you finish the last double crochet stitch in the row, turn the foundation row to the side. This will make it easier for you to access the stitches that you need to crochet around in the next row. Crocheting the First Row of Scales Chain 3 and work 3 double crochet stitches under the post. Loop the yarn over the hook and pull it through to make a chain. Then, repeat this sequence 2 more times to make a total of 3 chain stitches. This chain of 3 will count as a double crochet stitch. Follow the chain with 3 double crochet stitches worked under the post of the first double crochet stitch in the row.Tip: Make sure to keep the working yarn taut as you work to ensure that the stitches are not too loose. Chain 1. After you complete the third double crochet stitch, make a chain of 1. This will provide some slack between the rows of double crochet stitches and help to form the scale shape. Double crochet 4 times around the next post. Turn the work to the opposite side and locate the next post. Use your fingers to pull it out slightly so that it is easier for you to access it. Then, work 4 double crochet stitches under the post to complete the first scale. Make sure that the bases of these stitches are facing the bases of the first 4 double crochet stitches. Skip the next 2 stitches. After you complete the first scale, skip the next 2 stitches in the row. This will create space between the scales and make them more visible. Repeat the sequence to the end of the row. After you have completed 1 scale, repeat the sequence to make more scales. However, instead of chaining 3 to begin the next stitch, simply double crochet 4 times around the post. Then, chain 1, double crochet 4 times around the next post, and skip 2 as before. Working the Second Foundation Row Chain 3 and turn your work. Once you have finished working your first row of scales, make a chain of 3. Loop the yarn over the hook and pull through to make the first chain. Repeat this 2 more times. Then, turn your work around so that you are looking at it from the opposite side.Tip: Always hold your hook in your dominant hand. If you are right-handed, hold the hook in your right hand. If you are left-handed, hold the hook in your left hand. Double crochet into the first stitch in the row. Locate the first stitch in the row and then work a double crochet stitch through it. Yarn over your hook, pull it through 1. Then, yarn over again and pull through 2. Yarn over again 1 more time and pull through 2 again to complete the stitch. This will help to smooth out the work and create a foundation for the next row of scales. Work a double crochet stitch into the center of the first crocodile stitch. Locate the space in between the 2 rows if double crochet stitches from your previous row. Then, yarn over your hook and insert the hook into this space. Complete 1 double crochet stitch into the space of this stitch. Slipstitch and double crochet 1 time between the scales. Insert the crochet hook through the 2 layers of stitches in between the first set of scales. Then, loop the yarn over the hook and pull it all the way through the scales. Loop the yarn over the hook again and work a double crochet stitch through the scales. These are the spaces you skipped in the last row. Repeat the stitch sequence to the end of the row. Continue to work the same pattern for the rest of the row. This will complete the second foundation row and allow you to add more scale rows. When you are ready to finish your project, make sure to work a foundation row as your last row. Repeat the last 2 rows to add more scales. After you have completed your second foundation row, work another row of scales. The, follow that with another foundation row. Keep repeating this sequence of rows until your work is the desired length. Cut and tie off your work as usual when you have completed your project.
sentences: Creating the Foundation Row Make a slip knot and place it onto your crochet hook.
Wrap your working yarn around your index and middle finger twice.
Then, pull the first loop on your hook over the second loop on your hook.
Place the loop on your crochet hook.
Then, tug the tail of your yarn to tighten the loop.
Choose a crochet hook and yarn that are compatible.
Check the yarn label for a hook size recommendation if you are unsure.
Chain 21.
With the slipknot on the hook, wrap your working yarn over your hook 1 time and pull this yarn through the slip knot.
This new loop is your first chain.
To make another chain, bring the yarn over the hook, and pull it through the loop again.
Keep going until you have made a chain of 21.Tip: Make sure to keep the working yarn taut as you crochet to ensure that your chain is not too loose.
Double crochet into the fourth chain from the hook.
Wrap the yarn over the hook 1 time and then insert it into the fourth chain from the hook.
Yarn over the hook again and pull the yarn through the chain.
Then, yarn over again and pull through 2 loops.
Yarn over 1 more time, and pull through the remaining 2 loops to complete the stitch.
This completes 1 double crochet stitch and the chain stitches next to the stitch also count as a double crochet stitch.
Double crochet 1 time into each chain.
To complete the foundation row, double crochet 1 time into every chain in the row.
Go all the way to the end of the chain.
Make sure to keep the chain straight as you work to avoid twisting the stitches.
Turn your work to the side at the end of the row.
After you finish the last double crochet stitch in the row, turn the foundation row to the side.
This will make it easier for you to access the stitches that you need to crochet around in the next row.
Crocheting the First Row of Scales Chain 3 and work 3 double crochet stitches under the post.
Loop the yarn over the hook and pull it through to make a chain.
Then, repeat this sequence 2 more times to make a total of 3 chain stitches.
This chain of 3 will count as a double crochet stitch.

Follow the chain with 3 double crochet stitches worked under the post of the first double crochet stitch in the row.Tip: Make sure to keep the working yarn taut as you work to ensure that the stitches are not too loose.
Chain 1.
After you complete the third double crochet stitch, make a chain of 1.
This will provide some slack between the rows of double crochet stitches and help to form the scale shape.
Double crochet 4 times around the next post.
Turn the work to the opposite side and locate the next post.
Use your fingers to pull it out slightly so that it is easier for you to access it.
Then, work 4 double crochet stitches under the post to complete the first scale.
Make sure that the bases of these stitches are facing the bases of the first 4 double crochet stitches.
Skip the next 2 stitches.
After you complete the first scale, skip the next 2 stitches in the row.
This will create space between the scales and make them more visible.
Repeat the sequence to the end of the row.
After you have completed 1 scale, repeat the sequence to make more scales.
However, instead of chaining 3 to begin the next stitch, simply double crochet 4 times around the post.
Then, chain 1, double crochet 4 times around the next post, and skip 2 as before.
Working the Second Foundation Row Chain 3 and turn your work.
Once you have finished working your first row of scales, make a chain of 3.
Loop the yarn over the hook and pull through to make the first chain.
Repeat this 2 more times.
Then, turn your work around so that you are looking at it from the opposite side.Tip: Always hold your hook in your dominant hand.
If you are right-handed, hold the hook in your right hand.
If you are left-handed, hold the hook in your left hand.
Double crochet into the first stitch in the row.
Locate the first stitch in the row and then work a double crochet stitch through it.
Yarn over your hook, pull it through 1.
Then, yarn over again and pull through 2.
Yarn over again 1 more time and pull through 2 again to complete the stitch.
This will help to smooth out the work and create a foundation for the next row of scales.
Work a double crochet stitch into the center of the first crocodile stitch.
Locate the space in between the 2 rows if double crochet stitches from your previous row.
Then, yarn over your hook and insert the hook into this space.
Complete 1 double crochet stitch into the space of this stitch.
Slipstitch and double crochet 1 time between the scales.
Insert the crochet hook through the 2 layers of stitches in between the first set of scales.
Then, loop the yarn over the hook and pull it all the way through the scales.
Loop the yarn over the hook again and work a double crochet stitch through the scales.
These are the spaces you skipped in the last row.
Repeat the stitch sequence to the end of the row.
Continue to work the same pattern for the rest of the row.
This will complete the second foundation row and allow you to add more scale rows.
When you are ready to finish your project, make sure to work a foundation row as your last row.
Repeat the last 2 rows to add more scales.
After you have completed your second foundation row, work another row of scales.
The, follow that with another foundation row.
Keep repeating this sequence of rows until your work is the desired length.
Cut and tie off your work as usual when you have completed your project.
